intro: Brassica oleracea var. gemmifera, commonly known as the cauliflower, is a cultivar of the cabbage family characterized by its dense, white curds formed by the tightly packed flower buds. The plant is an annual or biennial herb, typically growing to a height of 40–60 cm, with a short, thick stem and broad, dark green leaves. Its inflorescence consists of undeveloped flowers that remain in a compact, rounded cluster, giving it a distinctive appearance. The curds are harvested before the flowers open, ensuring a tender and edible texture. This variety is widely cultivated for its nutritional value and use in various cuisines around the world.
